info.game_comments:
2008-B Teen Tournament semifinal game 2.

Ask Alex #4: Funniest thing.

(1, 1).clue: A Texas MSA is Arlington, Dallas & this partner of Dallas

(2, 1).clue: Pollution in Lake Springfield dooms the town in this film

(3, 1).clue: The Magna Carta was approved near London at Runnymede; a small meadow on this river

(4, 1).clue: The whine of this dental excavator is frightening as well as noisy

(5, 1).clue: The special edition of this Guitar Hero competitor comes with guitar, mic & drum kit peripherals

(1, 2).clue: This state's MSAs include Harrisburg-Carlisle & Scranton-Wilkes-Barre

(2, 2).clue: In this Jerry Seinfeld film, eating honey brings on a class action lawsuit

(3, 2).clue: The introductory section of the Magna Carta is known as this, just like the intro to the U.S. Constitution

(4, 2).clue: It seems like somebody turned the lowing of these animals on high

(5, 2).clue: Accessories for this Nintendo game system include boxing gloves, a dancing mat & a balance board

(1, 3).clue: You'll be Racine to your buzzers with the MSA Racine, in this state

(2, 3).clue: Seen here is this movie about penguins who don't sing or dance

(3, 3).clue: Fearing its limits on the clergy, this man officially annulled the document after a few months

(4, 3).clue: A New Jersey motorcycle rally is rhymingly called this "to the Shore"

(5, 3).clue: Use a device that creates doors in the unlikeliest of places in this futuristic game from Valve

(6, 3).clue: Thyme, crime, dime, grime, lime, mime, slime

(1, 4).clue: Ogden & this city grew almost 25% between 1990 & 2000

(2, 4).clue: The sequel to this 2002 animated movie was subtitled "The Meltdown"

(3, 4).clue: This English king was forced to agree to the Magna Carta after a group of Barons captured London

(4, 4).clue: It's the "seismic" name of the stereo company that makes the Supernova subwoofer

(5, 4).clue: The year is 1720 in the Sony Online Entertainment game named these swarthy types "of the Burning Sea"

(6, 4).clue: The hay,the road,the nail right on the head

(1, 5).clue: These same-named Midwest cities in 2 neighboring states combine into one metro area with nearly 2 million people

(2, 5).clue: An evil stepmother is out to ruin not just Cinderella's storybook existence, but all fairy tales in this 2006 film

(3, 5).clue: In 1957 the ABA, this group, acknowledge the debt U.S. law owed the Magna Carta & erected a U.K. monument

(4, 5).clue: I called 703-417-8020 about noise at this facility named for Ronald Reagan, but couldn't hear the person talk

(5, 5).clue: MMORPGers rejoice & play the "Hyborian Adventures" of this swordsman created by Robert E. Howard

(1, 1).clue: Around 1325 B.C. this boy king was buried in a gold mask inside 4 coffins, one of which was made of gold

(2, 1).clue: The Canadian version of this sport has 12 men on a side, & the field is 110 yards long

(3, 1).clue: After a female ant mates & loses her wings, she becomes one of these

(4, 1).clue: Wearing costumes on this day goes back to a medieval practice of dressing as angels & demons

(5, 1).clue: His son Wolfgang Jr. was a pupil of Salieri

(1, 2).clue: In 1542 this 50ish SWK (single white king) was looking for lucky wife No. 6

(2, 2).clue: Dating back to Ancient Egypt, this sport, also called kegling, can keep you in the gutter

(3, 2).clue: The "med" in the name medfly refers to this region where it can damage olive trees

(4, 2).clue: Every spring Washington Square Park in NYC holds a fiesta for these "wiener dogs" & their owners

(5, 2).clue: This Russian collaborated on "Swan Lake" with choreographer Marius Petipa

(1, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew delivers the clue from Mount Vernon.)  This is where Washington planned  for this 1781 battle, one of the most skillful military operations in history

(2, 3).clue: Taking its name from the French for "sled", this sport held its first international race in 1883

(3, 3).clue: This luxurious fabric of Asia is produced by the larva of the insect Bombyx mori

(4, 3).clue: This Christian holy day can occur as early as March 22 or as late as April 25

(5, 3).clue: After his "Rhapsody In Blue", this American composer gave us a "Second Rhapsody"

(1, 4).clue: At age 70, this Athenian was put on trial for "not believing in the gods the state believes in"

(2, 4).clue: Originating in Persia, this sport gained popularity with British officers in India who liked horsing around

(3, 4).clue: One of Japan's most complex kites is the mukade-dako, formed of jointed sections to look like this insect

(4, 4).clue: Look for the Ancient Order of Hibernians in this parade that has marched up 5th Ave. every year since 1762

(5, 4).clue: Born in 1810, this pianist studied harmony at the Warsaw Conservatory

(1, 5).clue: The only monarch representing a state in the National Statuary Hall represents this state

(2, 5).clue: In 1843 Norway held the first competition in the Nordic type of this winter sport

(3, 5).clue: Seen here on cotton, it can be a threat to crops in the southern United States

(4, 5).clue: Limerick Day, May 12, coincides with the birthday of this "Owl and the Pussy-cat" poet who popularized limericks

(5, 5).clue: First performed in Cairo, this Verdi opera was commissioned by the Khedive of Egypt

(0, 0).clue: In a 1914 novel, as a boy he could "drop twenty feet at a stretch from limb to limb in rapid descent to the ground"
